title.narrative: Provision of Protection Services to Conflict-Affected IDPs in Badghis Province

description.narrative: The project aims to provide protection services to conflict-affected populations in hard to reach districts (Ab Kamari and Qades) of Badghis province. The project is based on rigorous needs assessments performed through a UNHCR funded project " IPD Protection Monitoring and Emergency Response Project" in which CRDSA along with IRC, NRC and provincial DoRR representatives assess the protection needs of the newly displaced families in Badghis province which identified 15 villages including Dehestian, Tashboolaq, Branghariha, Khoche Zard, Chalanak ha, Surakhak, Sanglaw (Ab Kamari district), Chap rood, Khod amadaha, Arbab Ali, Khalifa Ayaz, Gharchaghai, Omar Big, Zad Saleh, Haji Qurban (Qades district) with extensive protection risks among women and children. Protection assistance through the project consists of two components namely GBV prevention/response and child protection. The first component (GBV prevention and response) is providing protection assistance to address GBV among the target displaced population and host communities in the 15 named villages. The component will contribute to the cluster objectives through 3 specific interventions including 1) provision of awareness regarding GBV and ways to prevent/respond it to 2360 newly displaced individuals 2) establishment of 15 Community-Based Human Rights Committees (CBHRCs) that will work to prevent and respond to GBV using community-based approaches in the respective communities based on a CBHRC model developed by CRDSA and 3) identification of 220 GBV survivors and providing case management services including psychosocial counselling and referral to specialized health, legal and safety services. The second component (child protection) is providing protection assistance to displaced and host community children in the 15 target villages. The protection assistance includes 1) positive parenthood skills awareness raising for 1200 parents to prevent physical and psychological violence (which is increasing in emergency situation) against children, 2) providing child-friendly spaces to 4000 children to minimize the effects of the emergency on their psychosocial well-being and development, and 3) supporting 600 children who are unable to attend the school by minimizing formal/familial barriers and providing of a school-entry kit (including stationaries and a bag).
